Since $\left\{u_{l, j}\right\}_{j \geq 1}$ was obtained by applying the Gram-Schmidt procedure to $\left\{\rho(g) e_{l}\right\}_{g \in \pi_{1}(S)}$, the functions $h_{l, j \geq 1}^{\epsilon}$ determine uniquely a family of functions

$$
\left\{k_{l, g}^{\epsilon}: \mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta} \mapsto \mathbb{R}\right\}_{l \geq 1, g \in \pi_{1}(S)}
$$

such that for any $x \in \mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}$,

$$
\varphi^{\epsilon}(x)=\sum_{l \geq 1} \sum_{g \in \pi_{1}(S)} k_{l, g}^{\epsilon}(x) \rho(g) e_{l}
$$

and for all but finitely many $l \geq 1$ and $g \in \pi_{1}(S)$, we have $k_{l, g}^{\epsilon}(x)=0$ for any $x$.

By our assumption that $\rho \prec \nu$, for any $l \geq 0$, for all $\epsilon_{1}$ and every finite subset $Q \subset \pi_{1}(S)$, there exist $\eta_{l, 1}, \ldots, \eta_{l, m}$ in $K$ such that for all $g \in Q$,

$$
\left|\left\langle\rho(g) e_{l}, e_{l}\right\rangle-\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left\langle\nu(g) \eta_{l, j}, \eta_{l, j}\right\rangle\right|<\epsilon_{1}
$$

We can reformulate that by saying the following: for any $l \geq 0$, for all $\epsilon_{1}$ and every finite subset $Q \subset \pi_{1}(S)$, there exist $\eta_{l}$ in $\bigoplus^{\infty} K$ such that for all $g \in Q$,

$$
\left|\left\langle\rho(g) e_{l}, e_{l}\right\rangle-\left\langle\bigoplus^{\infty} \nu(g) \eta_{l}, \eta_{l}\right\rangle\right|<\epsilon_{1}
$$

Moreover, if $l_{1} \neq l_{2}$, then the subspace generated by $\eta_{l_{1}}$ is orthogonal to the one generated by $\eta_{l_{2}}$ inside $\bigoplus^{\infty} K$. Inspecting the inequality for $g=e$ the unit element, we can assume that each $\eta_{l}$ has norm one.

We choose the finite subset $Q \subset \pi_{1}(S)$ so that it contains all elements of the form $g_{1}^{-1} g_{2}$ where $g_{1}, g_{2} \in \pi_{1}(S)$ are such that $k_{l, g_{1}}^{\epsilon}\left(x_{1}\right) \neq 0, k_{l, g_{2}}^{\epsilon}\left(x_{2}\right) \neq 0$ for some $l \geq 1$ and some $x_{1}, x_{2} \in \mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}$. Given $\epsilon_{1}>0$, let $\eta_{l} \in \bigoplus^{\infty} K$ be as above. Define the approximation map

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}: \mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K} \\
x \in \mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta} \mapsto \frac{1}{\left\|\sum_{l \geq 1} \sum_{g \in \pi_{1}(S)} k_{l, g}^{\epsilon}(x) \bigoplus^{\infty} \nu(g) \eta_{l}\right\|} \sum_{l \geq 1} \sum_{g \in \pi_{1}(S)} k_{l, g}^{\epsilon}(x) \bigoplus^{\infty} \nu(g) \eta_{l}
\end{gathered}
$$

By (15) and using that the unitary representations $\rho$ and $\bigoplus^{\infty} \nu$ preserve scalar products, this map is well-defined for $\epsilon_{1}$ small enough since then, the vector on the right side above is nowhere vanishing. By (15) again, for any $\epsilon^{\prime}$, if $\epsilon_{1}$ is chosen small enough, then $\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}$ and $\varphi^{\epsilon}$ satisfy:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\left(\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}\right)^{*} g_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}-\left(\varphi^{\epsilon}\right)^{*} g_{H}\right\|_{C^{3}\left(\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}\right)} \leq \epsilon^{\prime} / 3 \\
\left|\mathrm{E}\left(\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)-\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\varphi^{\epsilon}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)\right|<\epsilon^{\prime} / 3
\end{gathered}
$$

It remains to construct from $\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}$ a nearby map that is the restriction to $\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}$ of a $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariant map from $\tilde{A}_{\delta}$ to $\mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}$. Let us call $s_{1}, \ldots, s_{j}, \ldots$ the finitely many sides of the polygon $\overline{\mathbf{D}}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}$. For any side $s_{j}$ of $\overline{\mathbf{D}}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}$, if $g . s_{j}$ is another side $s_{k}$ of $\overline{\mathbf{D}}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}$ for some $g \in \pi_{1}(S)$, then by $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariance of $\varphi$, the two maps $\varphi \circ g: s_{j} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{H}$ and $\rho(g) \circ \varphi: s_{j} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{H}$ are equal. It is then clear that if $\epsilon, \epsilon_{1}$ are small enough, $\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon} \circ g: s_{j} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}$ and $\bigoplus^{\infty} \nu(g) \circ \mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}: s_{j} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}$ are arbitrarily close in the $C^{\infty}$-topology. One can make them equal by a small perturbation of $\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}$. Repeating this for every side $s_{j}$, it is then quite elementary to perturb the map $\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}$ to get a new map

$$
\mathscr{A}_{0}^{\epsilon}: \overline{\mathbf{D}}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}
$$

such that $\mathscr{A}_{0}^{\epsilon}$ is the restriction of a smooth $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariant map

$$
\varphi^{\prime}: \tilde{A}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}
$$

and

$$
\left\|\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}-\left(\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}\right)^{*} g_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}\right\|_{C^{3}\left(\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}\right)} \leq \epsilon^{\prime} / 3
$$

$$
\left|\mathrm{E}\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)-\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)\left|<\epsilon^{\prime} / 3\right.
$$

Combining the previous inequalities, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\varphi^{\prime}-\varphi\right\|_{C^{3}\left(\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}\right)} \leq \epsilon^{\prime} \\
\left|\mathrm{E}\left(\varphi^{\prime}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)-\left.\mathrm{E}\left(\varphi\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)\left|<\epsilon^{\prime}\right.
\end{gathered}
$$

Property (1) of the proposition is proved.
To show (2), note that if $\rho$ is irreducible, then $H$ is generated by $\left\{\rho(g) e_{1}\right\}_{g \in \pi_{1}(S)}$ (i.e. there is only one nonzero vector $e_{l}$ ). Moreover, since $\rho \prec \nu$, if $K=\bigoplus_{m=1}^{\infty} K_{m}$, $\nu=\bigoplus_{m=1}^{\infty} \nu_{m}$, then (15) holds with $\eta_{1}$ belonging to some $K_{m}$ instead of $\bigoplus^{\infty} K$. Indeed, this follows from the proof of [BdLHV08, Proposition F.1.4] (in its proof, replace $\mathcal{F}$ by the set of normalized functions of positive type on $\pi_{1}(S)$ of the form $\langle\nu(. \xi, \xi\rangle$ where $\left.\xi \in \bigcup_{m=1}^{\infty} K_{m}\right)$. Thus, the approximations $\mathscr{A}^{\epsilon}$ and $\mathscr{A}_{0}^{\epsilon}$ can be chosen to take values in $\mathbb{S}_{K_{m}}$ instead of $\mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}$, and so $\varphi^{\prime}$ can be chosen to take values in $\mathbb{S}_{K_{m}}$ instead of $\mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}$.
3.2. Extending equivariant maps. Below, we explain how to equivariantly extend a map from a compact subset of a universal cover (like those produced in the previous subsection) to the whole universal cover, in such a way that the renormalized energy on a fundamental domain remains controlled. A necessary and sufficient condition for a pair $(S, \rho)$ to have finite (non-renormalized) energy is also given in this subsection.

Let $S$ be a punctured Riemann, with a fundamental domain $\mathbf{D}_{S} \subset \tilde{S}$ as before, and let $\operatorname{Punc}_{S}$ be the set of punctures $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{\mathbf{n}}$ of $S$. Let $\rho: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{End}(V)$ be a unitary representation (possibly of infinite dimension), $\mathbb{S}_{V}$ the unit sphere of the Hilbert space $V$. Let $\mathscr{H}_{S, \rho}$ be the space of smooth equivariant maps defined in (1). Given $p \in \operatorname{Punc}_{S}$, the quantity $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(p)$ was defined in (3).

Preparation and some notations: Let $\delta \in(0,1]$. If $\mathbf{n}>0$, let $A_{\delta} \subset S$ and $\tilde{A}_{\delta} \subset \tilde{S}$ be as in (14). By convention, if $\mathbf{n}=0, A_{\delta}=S$. Let $\gamma_{1}, \ldots, \gamma_{\mathbf{n}}$ be elements of the fundamental group which can be represented by oriented embedded loops around the respective punctures $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{\mathbf{n}}$. Those elements are uniquely determined up to conjugacy. Those loops are freely homotopic to the boundary components of $A_{\delta}$.

Let

$$
\Pi: \tilde{S} \rightarrow S
$$

be the natural projection. Consider the complement $\tilde{A}_{\delta}^{c}$ of $\tilde{A}_{\delta}$ inside $\tilde{S}$. The region $\tilde{A}_{\delta}^{c}$ is a disjoint union of connected components, each of which is mapped to an embedded punctured disk inside $S$ under the projection $\Pi$. For each $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$, recall that we fixed a conformal parameterization

$$
P_{p_{q}}: D\left(p_{q}, 1\right) \rightarrow \mathbb{D}^{*}
$$

and defined $D\left(p_{q}, r\right)$ in (2). Let us also fix a standard conformal diffeomorphism from $\mathbb{D}^{*}$ to the half-infinite cylinder

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{Q}: \quad \mathbb{D}^{*} & \rightarrow\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq 0\} / z \mapsto z+2 \pi \\
(\theta, r) & \mapsto\left(\theta, \log \frac{1}{r}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For each $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$, consider a connected component $C_{\delta, q}$ of $\tilde{A}_{\delta}^{c}$ left invariant by the cyclic subgroup $\left\langle\gamma_{q}\right\rangle$ (this component is uniquely defined). By lifting the conformal parameterization $\mathcal{Q} \circ P_{p_{q}}$ to $C_{\delta, q}$, the closure of the connected component $C_{\delta, q}$ is conformal to

$$
\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}
$$

In this conformal parametrization, $\gamma_{q}$ acts by translation $z \mapsto z+2 \pi$. Note that

$$
\tilde{A}_{\delta}^{c}=\bigcup_{q=1}^{\mathbf{n}} \Pi^{-1}\left(\Pi\left(C_{\delta, q}\right)\right)
$$

Lemma 3.2. Let $\delta \in(0,1]$. Consider a smooth $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariant map $\varphi_{0}: \tilde{A}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}$ with respect to $\rho$, such that for some $\bar{L}>0$, for each $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$,

$$
\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2} \leq \bar{L}
$$

Then there is a constant $C=C(\bar{L})>0$ such that the following holds:
(1) if $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(p)=0$ for all $p \in \operatorname{Punc}_{S}$, then there is a map $\hat{\varphi} \in \mathscr{H}_{S, \rho}$ such that

$$
\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\hat{\varphi}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right) \leq \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\varphi_{0}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)+C \sum_{q=1}^{\mathbf{n}} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}
$$

(2) if $\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{S}} V<\infty$, then there is a map $\hat{\varphi} \in \mathscr{H}_{S, \rho}$ such that

$$
\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(\left.\hat{\varphi}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right) \leq \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\varphi_{0}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)+C \sum_{q=1}^{\mathbf{n}} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}
$$

Proof. The lemma is only nontrivial when there are some punctures, so we will assume in this proof that $\mathbf{n}>0$. Let $\delta \in(0,1]$. Consider the given smooth $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariant map $\varphi_{0}: \tilde{A}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}$. Since $\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}$ is compact, $\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\varphi_{0}\right)\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\rangle<\infty$. We want to extend this map to a map from the whole $\bar{S}$ with (renormalized) energy controlled in terms of $\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\varphi_{0}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)$ and the boundary integral $\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}$.

Case (1): The assumption that $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(p)=0$ for all $p \in \operatorname{Punc}_{S}$ means the following: for each $j \geq 1$, there is a vector $v_{q, j} \in \mathbb{S}_{V}$ and some length-minimizing geodesic segment $\beta_{j}$ from $v_{q, j}$ to $\rho\left(\gamma_{q}\right) v_{q, j}$ with length converging to 0 as $j \rightarrow \infty$. Consider a small constant

$$
\alpha \in\left(0,10^{-10}\right)
$$

which will be fixed later. After taking a subsequence in $j$, we can assume without loss of generality that

$$
\operatorname{Length}\left(\beta_{j}\right) \leq \alpha e^{-j}
$$

Furthermore, by changing $v_{q, j}$ to its opposite $-v_{q, j}$, we can assume without loss of generality that for any $j$

$$
\operatorname{dist}_{\mathbb{S}_{V}}\left(v_{q, j}, v_{q, j+1}\right) \leq \frac{\pi}{2}
$$

We can also assume (after taking the opposite of the $v_{q, j}$ 's if necessary) that

$$
\operatorname{dist}_{\mathbb{S}_{V}}\left(\varphi_{0}\left(\left(0, \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)\right), v_{q, 1}\right) \leq \frac{\pi}{2}
$$

Fix momentarily $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$ and consider a corresponding component $C_{\delta, q}$ of $\tilde{A}_{\delta}^{c}$ as before the lemma. By a slight abuse of notations, we identify any map $\phi: C_{\delta, q} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}$ (resp. $\phi: \partial C_{\delta, q} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}$ ) with the corresponding map

$$
\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V} \quad\left(\text { resp. } \quad \partial\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}\right)
$$

induced by the conformal parametrization fixed above. We will first define a new map $\varphi_{1}$ on $\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}$, which we require to be equivariant, to coincide with $\varphi_{0}$ on the boundary $\partial\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}$, and such that the area of the image of $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$ has controlled area. Then, we will use a reparameterization trick to obtain a map $\varphi_{2}$ with controlled energy on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$.

We start by setting $\varphi_{1}=\varphi_{0}$ on the boundary $\partial\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}=$ $\mathbb{R} \times\left\{\log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}$. By an arbitrarily small perturbation of $\varphi_{0}$, we can assume (without loss of generality for the proof) that the restriction of $\varphi_{1}$ to $\partial\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq 1\right\}=\mathbb{R} \times\{1\}$ is an immersion. On the square $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right] \subset\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}$, we extend $\varphi_{1}$ in such a way that

- $\varphi_{1}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right)$ is a parameterization proportional to arclength of the curve $\varphi_{1}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)$, in other words

$$
\forall t \in[0,2 \pi], \quad\left|\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \varphi_{1}\left(t, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right)\right|=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left|\frac{\partial}{\partial t^{\prime}} \varphi_{1}\left(t^{\prime}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)\right| d t^{\prime}
$$

- when $s \in\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right], \varphi_{1}(., s)$ is the natural linear interpolation between the two parameterizations $\varphi_{1}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)$ and $\varphi_{1}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right)$, namely if we set $\gamma(.):=$ $\varphi_{1}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right)$ and view it as a bijection onto its image,
$\forall(t, s) \in[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right], \quad \varphi_{1}(t, s)=\gamma\left[\left(s-\log \frac{1}{\delta}\right) t+\left(1-s+\log \frac{1}{\delta}\right) \gamma^{-1}\left(\varphi_{1}\left(t, \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)\right)\right]$.

By those two properties, plus the assumption in the lemma, we estimate easily that

$$
\int_{[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right]}\left|d \varphi_{1}\right|^{2} \leq C_{(0)} \int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2} \leq C_{(0)} \sqrt{\bar{L}} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}
$$

for some constant $C_{(0)}$ depending only on $\bar{L}$. Here the energy is computed using the standard Euclidean metric $g_{\text {Eucl }}$ on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right]$.

Next set

$$
\varphi_{1}:[0,2 \pi] \times\left\{\log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right\} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}
$$

to be the geodesic $\beta_{2}$ from $\varphi_{1}\left(0, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right):=v_{q, 2}$ to $\varphi_{1}\left(2 \pi, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right):=\rho\left(\gamma_{q}\right) v_{q, 2}$, parametrized proportionally to arclength. From the previous paragraph, $\gamma(.):=\varphi_{1}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}+\right.$ 1) : $[0,2 \pi] \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}$ is a parameterization proportional to arclength of the curve $\varphi_{1}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)$, and

$$
\operatorname{Length}(\gamma)=\int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left|\frac{\partial}{\partial t^{\prime}} \varphi_{1}\left(t^{\prime}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)\right| d t^{\prime} \leq \sqrt{2 \pi} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}} \leq \sqrt{2 \pi} \sqrt{\bar{L}}
$$

We claim that for some constant $C_{(1)}$ depending only on $\bar{L}$, we can extend $\varphi_{1}$ to the region $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+1, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right]$ with a map whose differential satisfies at all $(x, y) \in$ $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+1, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right]$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\frac{\partial \varphi_{1}}{\partial x}\right| \leq C_{(1)}\left[\left(1-\left(y-\log \frac{1}{\delta}-1\right)\right) \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+\left(y-\log \frac{1}{\delta}-1\right) \operatorname{Length}\left(\beta_{2}\right)\right] \\
& \left|\frac{\partial \varphi_{1}}{\partial y}\right| \leq C_{(1)}
\end{aligned}
$$

If the length of $\gamma$ is smaller than say $10^{-10}$, such an extension can be cosntructed for instance by interpolating linearly between $\gamma$ and $\beta_{2}$ inside the Hilbert space $V$, using (18) and radially projecting the interpolation to the sphere $\mathbb{S}_{V}$. If the length of $\gamma$ is between $10^{-10}$ and $\sqrt{2 \pi} \sqrt{\bar{L}}$ (which is always an upper bound by (20)), such an extension exists by an argument by contradiction and a compactness argument. This justifies the claim.

For each $j \geq 3$, set

$$
\varphi_{1}:[0,2 \pi] \times\left\{\log \frac{1}{\delta}+j\right\} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}
$$

to be the geodesic $\beta_{j}$ from $\varphi_{1}\left(0, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+j\right):=v_{q, j}$ to $\varphi_{1}\left(2 \pi, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+j\right):=\rho\left(\gamma_{q}\right) v_{q, j}$, parametrized proportionally to arclength. For any $j \geq 2$ and $t \in[0,2 \pi]$, define

$$
\varphi_{1}:\{t\} \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+j, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+j+1\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}
$$

to be a geodesic segment of length less than $\pi$ from $\varphi_{1}\left(\left(t, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+j\right)\right)$ to $\varphi_{1}\left(\left(t, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+j+1\right)\right)$ parametrized proportionally to arclength. By (16) and (17), $\varphi_{1}$ is well-defined and

smooth on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+j, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+j+1\right]$. Moreover, it is elementary to check that for some constant $C_{(2)}$ depending only on $\bar{L}$, at any point $(x, y) \in[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+j, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+\right.$ $j+1]:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\frac{\partial \varphi_{1}}{\partial x}\right| \leq C_{(2)}\left[\left(1-\left(y-\log \frac{1}{\delta}-j\right)\right) \operatorname{Length}\left(\beta_{j}\right)+\left(y-\log \frac{1}{\delta}-j\right) \operatorname{Length}\left(\beta_{j}+1\right)\right] \\
& \left|\frac{\partial \varphi_{1}}{\partial y}\right| \leq C_{(2)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, the map $\varphi_{1}$ is extended to the whole band $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$, but it may not have controlled energy. On the other hand, it has bounded differential with respect to a metric which we construct now. We denote by $g_{\text {Eucl }}$ the standard Euclidean metric on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$. Let $g_{1}$ be the piecewise smooth Riemannian metric on $[0,2 \pi] \times$ $\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$ defined as follows:

- on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+1\right]$,

$$
g_{1}=\left(\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}\right) g_{\text {Eucl }}
$$

- on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+1, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right]$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
g_{1}= & {\left[\left(1-\left(y-\log \frac{1}{\delta}-1\right)\right) \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+\left(y-\log \frac{1}{\delta}-1\right) \operatorname{Length}\left(\beta_{2}\right)\right]^{2} d x^{2}+d y^{2} } \\
& \text { - for each } j \geq 2 \text {, on }[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+j, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+j+1\right] \\
& g_{1}=\left[\left(1-\left(y-\log \frac{1}{\delta}-j\right)\right) \operatorname{Length}\left(\beta_{j}\right)+\left(y-\log \frac{1}{\delta}-j\right) \operatorname{Length}\left(\beta_{j+1}\right)\right]^{2} d x^{2}+d y^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that this metric induces a metric on the cylinder $\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\} / z \mapsto z+2 \pi$ which is rotationally symmetric. Here is the key property of this metric: thanks to (21) and (22), we have with respect to $g_{1}$ :

$$
\left|d \varphi_{1}\right|_{g_{1}} \leq C_{(3)}
$$

on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+1, \infty\right)$ for a constant $C_{(3)}$ depending only on $\bar{L}$. In particular,

$$
\int_{[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)}\left|d \varphi_{1}\right|_{g_{1}}^{2} d v_{g_{1}} \leq C_{(0)} \sqrt{\bar{L}} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+C_{(3)}^{2} \operatorname{Area}\left([0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+1, \infty\right), g_{1}\right)
$$

where the first term on the right is due to (19) and conformal invariance of the energy. Because of the lengths bound for $\beta_{j}(16)$ and using the definition of $g_{1}$, we have for some constant $C_{(4)}$ depending only on $\bar{L}$,

$$
\operatorname{Area}\left([0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}+1, \infty\right), g_{1}\right) \leq C_{(4)}\left(\sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+\alpha\right)
$$

which implies with the previous inequality that

$$
\int_{[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)}\left|d \varphi_{1}\right|_{g_{1}}^{2} d v_{g_{1}} \leq\left(C_{(0)} \sqrt{\bar{L}}+C_{(3)}^{2} C_{(4)}\right)\left(\sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+\alpha\right)
$$

In order to get a map with controlled energy with respect to $g_{\text {Eucl }}$ instead of $g_{1}$, we can use a reparameterization trick. Since $g_{1}$ is rotationally symmetric on the cylinder $\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\} / z \mapsto z+2 \pi$, this Riemannian cylinder is conformal to a flat cylinder $\mathcal{C}$ which is either bounded or half-infinite, via a conformal map which is itself equivariant by rotations of the cylinder. Since the metric $g_{1}$ is of the form $f(y)^{2} d x^{2}+d y^{2}$ on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$ for all $y \in\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$ large enough, where $|f(y)| \leq 1$ by the length bound (16) for the $\beta_{j}$ 's, the flat cylinder $\mathcal{C}$ is necessarily half-infinite and we can take it to be $\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\} / z \mapsto z+2 \pi$ with the standard metric $g_{\text {Eucl }}$. After lifting to the universal covers, we obtain an equivariant, conformal diffeomorphism

$$
\mathcal{R}:\left(\mathbb{R} \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right), g_{\text {Eucl }}\right) \rightarrow\left(\mathbb{R} \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right), g_{1}\right)
$$

which restricts to the identity map on the boundary $\mathbb{R} \times\left\{\log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}$.
Consider the new map

$$
\varphi_{2}:=\varphi_{1} \circ \mathcal{R}:[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right) \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}
$$

By (23) and conformal invariance of the energy, this map satisfies for some constant $C_{(5)}$ depending only on $\bar{L}$ :

$$
\int_{[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)}\left|d \varphi_{2}\right|^{2} \leq C_{(5)}\left(\sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+\alpha\right)
$$

where the left-hand side is computed with respect to the Euclidean metric $g_{\text {Eucl }}$.
The map $\varphi_{2}$ defines, after imposing equivariance, a map from $\Pi^{-1}\left(\Pi\left(C_{\delta, q}\right)\right)$ to $\mathbb{S}_{V}$. Repeating the whole construction for each $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$, we obtain an equivariant map

$$
\varphi_{2}: \tilde{A}_{\delta}^{c} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}
$$

such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}^{c}}\left|d \varphi_{2}\right|^{2} & \leq C_{(5)} \sum_{q=1}^{\mathbf{n}}\left(\sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+\alpha\right) \\
& \leq C_{(5)} \sum_{q=1}^{\mathbf{n}} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+\mathbf{n} \alpha
\end{aligned}
$$

where the energy is computed with respect to the Euclidean metric $g_{\text {Eucl }}$. We can glue the maps $\varphi_{0}$ and $\varphi_{2}$ along the boundary of $\tilde{A}_{\delta}$ to obtain our final equivariant map

$\tilde{\varphi}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}$. It belongs to $\mathscr{H}_{S, \rho}$ after a smoothing, and its energy satisfies by (25):

$$
\left.\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\hat{\varphi}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right) \leq \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\varphi_{0}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right)+C_{(5)} \sum_{q=1}^{\mathbf{n}} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}|d \varphi_{0}|^{2}}+\mathbf{n} \alpha
$$

for a constant $C_{(5)}$ depending only on $\bar{L}$. The positive constant $\alpha>0$ could have been taken arbitrarily small. Either $\sum_{q=1}^{\mathbf{n}} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}|d \varphi_{0}|^{2}}>0$ and we can chose $\mathbf{n} \alpha$ to be smaller. Or $\sum_{q=1}^{\mathbf{n}} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}|d \varphi_{0}|^{2}}=0$, which means that $\varphi_{0}$ is constant on connected components of $\partial \tilde{A}_{\delta}$, so we could have taken the trivial extension instead of $\hat{\varphi}$ above. The trivial extension has same energy as $\varphi_{0}$. In both cases, we conclude Case (1).

Case (2): Let $\delta \in(0,1]$. We use the same notations as above. We also introduce the following notation. Given $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$, we have identified $C_{\delta, q}$ with $\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}$. Set

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{r}:\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\} \rightarrow[0, \infty) \\
\mathbf{r}: z \mapsto \exp (-\operatorname{Im}(z))
\end{gathered}
$$

In particular, $\mathbf{r}(z)=\delta$ for $z \in \partial\left\{z \in \mathbb{C} ; \quad \operatorname{Im}(z) \geq \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right\}$.
Fix $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$. By the assumption that $\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{R}} V<\infty$ and by compactness, there is a point $v_{q} \in \mathbb{S}_{V}$ and some length-minimizing geodesic segment parameterized by arclength

$$
\beta:[0,2 \pi] \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}
$$

such that $\beta(0)=v_{q}$ and $\beta(1)=\rho\left(\gamma_{q}\right) v_{q}$, and

$$
\operatorname{Length}(\beta)=\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(q)
$$

By changing $v_{q}$ to its opposite $-v_{q}$, we can assume without loss of generality that

$$
\operatorname{dist}_{\mathbb{S}_{V}}\left(\varphi_{0}\left(\left(0, \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right)\right), v_{q}\right) \leq \frac{\pi}{2}
$$

Next, we want to define an extension of $\varphi_{0}$ with controlled energy. We first extend $\varphi_{0}$ to a map $\varphi_{0}^{\prime}$ on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right]$ such that

$$
\varphi_{0}^{\prime}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right)=\beta
$$

Similar to the proof of Case (1), we choose $\varphi_{0}^{\prime}$ to have controlled energy and area on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right]$, and the reparameterization trick enables us to construct another extension $\varphi_{1}:[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, h\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}$ for some $h>\log \frac{1}{\delta}$, such that $\varphi_{1}(., h)=$

$\varphi_{0}^{\prime}\left(., \log \frac{1}{\delta}+2\right)$ and for a constant $C_{(6)}$ depending only on $\bar{L}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, h\right]}\left|d \varphi_{1}\right|^{2} & \leq C_{(6)}\left(\sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}+\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(q)\right) \\
& \leq C_{(6)}(1+\sqrt{2 \pi}) \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used that $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(q)=\operatorname{Length}(\beta) \leq \sqrt{2 \pi} \sqrt{\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}}$ by Cauchy-Schwarz. Then we extend $\varphi_{1}$ to $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$ by setting for all $(t, s) \in[0,2 \pi] \times[h, \infty)$,

$$
\varphi_{1}(t, s)=\beta(t)
$$

The "renormalized" energy of $\varphi_{1}$ on $[0,1] \times[h, \infty)$ satisfies

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0}\left[\left(\frac{1}{2} \int_{[0,2 \pi] \times[h, \infty)\backslash \mathbf{r}^{-1}((0, r))}\left|d \varphi_{1}\right|^{2}\right)-\frac{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}\left(p_{q}\right)^{2}}{4 \pi} \log \frac{1}{r}\right]=-\frac{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}\left(p_{q}\right)^{2}}{4 \pi} h \leq 0
$$

The "renormalized" energy of $\varphi_{1}$ on $[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, \infty\right)$ is thus at most $\int_{[0,2 \pi] \times\left[\log \frac{1}{\delta}, h\right]}\left|d \varphi_{1}\right|^{2}$, which is controlled by (27). Repeating this construction for every cusp, defining $\varphi_{1}$ on the whole universal cover $\tilde{S}$ by equivariance, and adding the previous estimates together, we conclude Case (2).

The following corollary contains a practical characterization of pairs $(S, \rho)$ with finite energy, and gives an a priori bound on $\mathrm{E}_{\text {ren }}(S, \rho)$.
Corollary 3.3. (1) $\mathrm{E}(S, \rho)<\infty$ if and only if $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(p)=0$ for all $p \in \operatorname{Punc}_{S}$.
(2) If $\operatorname{dim}_{\mathbb{R}} V<\infty$, the renormalized energy $\mathrm{E}_{\text {ren }}(S, \rho)$ is finite and bounded from above by a constant $C_{S}$ depending only on $S$.

Proof. Fix a triangulation of $S$ and any $\delta \in(0,1]$. By basic topological arguments, there is always a smooth $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariant map $\varphi_{0}: \tilde{A}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{V}$. Moreover, since the diameter of $\mathbb{S}_{V}$ is $\pi$, by straightening the map on the 1 -skeleton of the triangulation then extending the map by hand to the 2 -skeleton, $\varphi_{0}$ can be chosen so that $\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\varphi_{0}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right) \leq C_{S}^{\prime}$ and $\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q_{\delta}}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2}<C_{S}^{\prime}$ for all $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$, for some $C_{S}^{\prime}>0$ independent of $\rho$ or the dimension of $V$. Here $C_{\delta, q}$ is defined before Lemma 3.2.
(1): The implication $\forall p \in \operatorname{Punc}_{S}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(p)=0 \Rightarrow \mathrm{E}(S, \rho)<\infty$ is an easy consequence of Lemma 3.2 (1) and the existence of $\varphi_{0}$ explained above. Next, the direction $\mathrm{E}(S, \rho)<$ $\infty \Rightarrow \forall p \in \operatorname{Punc}_{S}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho}(p)=0$ follows from Fubini's theorem and was already showed in the proof of Lemma 1.4.
(2): This follows from Lemma 3.2 (2) and the existence of $\varphi_{0}$ explained above.

Corollary 3.4. (1) If $\rho: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{End}(V), \nu: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{End}(K)$ are unitary representations such that $\rho \prec \nu$, then

$$
\mathrm{E}(S, \bigoplus^{\infty} \nu) \leq \mathrm{E}(S, \rho)
$$

(2) If moreover $\rho$ is irreducible, $\nu=\bigoplus_{m=1}^{\infty} \nu_{m}$, then for any $\epsilon^{\prime \prime}>0$, there is $m_{0} \geq 1$ such that

$$
\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \nu_{m_{0}}\right) \leq \mathrm{E}(S, \rho)+\epsilon^{\prime \prime}
$$

Proof. (1): Suppose $\mathrm{E}(S, \rho)<\infty$, otherwise there is nothing to do. Consider a map $\varphi_{0} \in \mathscr{H}_{S, \rho}$ with finite energy on the fundamental domain $\mathbf{D}_{S}$. By Fubini's theorem as in the proof of Lemma 1.4, for any $\epsilon>0$, there is an arbitrarily small $\delta>0$ such that for any $q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}$,

$$
\int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}\right|^{2} \leq \epsilon
$$

where $C_{\delta, q}$ is defined before Lemma 3.2. By Proposition 3.1 (1), we get a smooth map $\varphi_{0}^{\prime}: \tilde{A}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{\bigoplus^{\infty} K}$, which is $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariant with respect to $\bigoplus^{\infty} \nu$, such that

$$
\left|\mathrm{E}\left(\varphi_{0}^{\prime}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)-\mathrm{E}\left(\varphi_{0}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}} \mid<\epsilon \quad \text { and } \quad \int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}^{\prime}\right|^{2} \leq 2 \epsilon \quad \text { for any } q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}
$$

Applying Lemma 3.2 (1) and letting $\epsilon \rightarrow 0$, we obtain $\mathrm{E}(S, \bigoplus^{\infty} \nu) \leq \mathrm{E}(S, \rho)$.
(2): Suppose moreover that $\rho$ is irreducible, and $\nu=\bigoplus_{m=1}^{\infty} \nu_{m}$ with $\nu_{m}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{End}\left(K_{m}\right)$. Using Proposition 3.1 (2), for any $\epsilon>0$, we get an $m_{0}=m_{0}(\epsilon) \geq 1$ and a smooth map $\varphi_{0}^{\prime \prime}: \tilde{A}_{\delta} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{K_{m_{0}}}$, which is $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariant with respect to $\nu_{m_{0}}$, such that

$$
\left|\mathrm{E}\left(\varphi_{0}^{\prime \prime}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)-\mathrm{E}\left(\varphi_{0}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}} \mid<\epsilon \quad \text { and } \quad \int_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \partial C_{\delta, q}}\left|d \varphi_{0}^{\prime \prime}\right|^{2} \leq 2 \epsilon \quad \text { for any } q \in\{1, \ldots, \mathbf{n}\}
$$

Applying Lemma 3.2 (2) and choosing $\epsilon$ small enough, we have $\mathrm{E}_{\text {ren }}\left(S, \nu_{m_{0}}\right) \leq \mathrm{E}(S, \rho)+$ $\epsilon^{\prime \prime}$ for any $\epsilon^{\prime \prime}>0$ fixed.

# 4. From strong CONVERGENCE to CONVERGENCE of HARMONIC MAPS 

We prove the main result, Theorem 0.4, in this section. Let us recall our assumptions and notations. Let $S$ be a punctured Riemann surface, with genus $\mathbf{g}$ and $\mathbf{n} \geq 0$ punctures. Suppose that $S$ has negative Euler characteristic $\chi(S)<0$. Let

$$
\rho_{j}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow U\left(N_{j}\right)
$$

be a sequence of unitary representations.

4.1. Convergence of the renormalized energy. In this subsection, we show that the first part of Theorem 0.4: strong convergence of a sequence of representations (see Subsection 6.2 in the Appendix) implies convergence of the renormalized energy.

Theorem 4.1. If $\rho_{j}$ strongly converges, then

$$
\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)=\frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)=\frac{\pi}{4}|\chi(S)|
$$

Note that $\frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)$ is exactly $\frac{1}{8} \operatorname{Area}\left(S, g_{\text {hyp }}\right)$, where $g_{\text {hyp }}$ is the unique complete, finite area, hyperbolic metric on $S$ compatible with its conformal structure. The theorem above will follow from Proposition 4.2 and Proposition 4.4 below.

Proposition 4.2. Under the previous assumptions,

$$
\limsup _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right) \leq \frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)
$$

Proof. Arguing towards a contradiction, let us assume that for some $\epsilon^{\prime \prime}>0$, there is a sequence $\left\{j_{m}\right\}_{m \geq 1}$ converging to $\infty$ such that

$$
\inf _{m \geq 1} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j_{m}}\right)>\frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)+\epsilon^{\prime \prime}
$$

Set

$$
\nu:=\bigoplus_{m \geq 1} \rho_{j_{m}}
$$

Let $\mathscr{P}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathcal{S}_{2}(\partial \tilde{S})$ and $\underline{\rho}_{B}$ be, respectively, the map in $\mathscr{H}_{S, \underline{\rho}_{B}}$ and boundary representation defined in (8) and (7). Note that since from Lemma 1.13 (1), $\underline{\rho}_{B} \sim \lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}$, we get

$$
\left\|\underline{\rho}_{B}(f)\right\|=\left\|\lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}(f)\right\| \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathbb{C}\left[\pi_{1}(S)\right]
$$

by Theorem 6.2. Since $\rho_{j}$ strongly converges by assumption,

$$
\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\rho_{j}(f)\right\|=\left\|\lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}(f)\right\| \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathbb{C}\left[\pi_{1}(S)\right]
$$

Hence, we clearly have

$$
\left\|\underline{\rho}_{B}(f)\right\| \leq\|\nu(f)\| \quad \text { for all } f \in \mathbb{C}\left[\pi_{1}(S)\right]
$$

which means according to Theorem 6.2 that $\underline{\rho}_{B} \prec \nu$. Next, we know from Lemma 1.13 that $\underline{\rho}_{B}$ is irreducible and $\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\mathscr{P}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)=\frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)$. We can then apply Corollary 3.4 (2) to $\rho:=\underline{\rho}_{B}, \nu:=\bigoplus_{m \geq 1} \rho_{j_{m}}$, and conclude that for some $m_{0} \geq 1$,

$$
\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j_{m_{0}}}\right) \leq \mathrm{E}\left(S, \underline{\rho}_{B}\right)+\epsilon^{\prime \prime} \leq \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\mathscr{P}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)+\epsilon^{\prime \prime}=\frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)+\epsilon^{\prime \prime}
$$

That contradicts (28), as wanted.

We observe an easy consequence of the strong convergence of $\rho_{j}$ (see (3) for the definition of $\left.\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho_{j}}(p)\right)$ :

Lemma 4.3. If $\rho_{j}$ strongly converges, for any puncture $p \in \operatorname{Punc}_{S}$, we have

$$
\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho_{j}}(p)=0
$$

Proof. Indeed, consider any element $g \in \pi_{1}(S)$ in the conjugacy class determined by small embedded oriented loops around $p$ in $S$. For any $\varepsilon>0$, there is a function $F_{\varepsilon} \in \ell^{2}\left(\pi_{1}(S)\right)$ of unit $L^{2}$-norm such that $\left\|\lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}(g) F_{\varepsilon}-F_{\varepsilon}\right\| \leq \varepsilon$ where $\lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}$ is the regular representation (e.g. take $F_{\varepsilon}$ to be constant on its support and supported on $\left\{g, g^{2}, \ldots, g^{N_{\varepsilon}}\right\}$ for some large integer $N_{\varepsilon}$ ). This implies in terms of operator norm: $\left\|\lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}(g)+\lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}(e)\right\|=2$ where $e \in \pi_{1}(S)$ is the identity element. By strong convergence, we have $\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\rho_{j}(g)+\rho_{j}(e)\right\|=2$. But this means by Cauchy-Schwarz that for any $\varepsilon>0$, for all large $j$, there are unit norm vectors $v_{j}$ such that $\left\|\rho_{j}(g) v_{j}-v_{j}\right\| \leq \varepsilon$, which is exactly the lemma.

The next proposition treats the opposite inequality. Its proof is the key place where the concept of strong convergence for representations is combined with harmonic maps. There, we construct a limit of harmonic maps, equivariant with respect to a limit representation, which we show is weakly equivalent to the regular representation.

Proposition 4.4. Under the above assumptions,

$$
\liminf _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right) \geq \frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)
$$

Proof. For each $j \geq 1$, let $\psi_{j}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}$ be a harmonic representative of $\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)$ : it is a harmonic map in $\mathscr{H}_{S, \rho_{j}}$ given by Theorem 1.7, so that

$$
\left.\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(\left.\psi_{j}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)=\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)\right.
$$

Due to Lemma 1.5, on every compact subset of $\mathbf{D}_{S}$, the energy of $\psi_{j}$ is uniformly bounded since $\mathrm{E}_{\text {ren }}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)$ is uniformly bounded thanks to Corollary 3.3 (2).

By standard harmonic map theory [SU82], after picking a subsequence and using the $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariance of the map $\psi_{j}$, a priori there are finitely many points $y_{1}, \ldots, y_{k} \in$ $\mathbf{D}_{S}$ where the energy might concentrate as $j \rightarrow \infty$. Using the $\epsilon$-regularity theorem, Theorem 1.8, we can replace $\psi_{j}$ in a small neighborhood of the $\pi_{1}(S)$-orbit of $\bigcup_{j=1}^{k} y_{j}$ equivariantly by a map with renormalized energy strictly smaller than $\psi_{j}$ for $j$ large. But since $\psi_{j}$ is energy minimizing among all smooth equivariant maps, we have a contradiction (this is the usual replacement argument appearing in [SU82, proof of Theorem 5.1] for instance). Thus, the energy of $\psi_{j}$ does not concentrate around any point as $j \rightarrow \infty$. Next, by the $\epsilon$-regularity theorem again, Theorem 1.8, on each compact subset of $\tilde{S}$, the maps $\psi_{j}$ are uniformly bounded in the $C^{m}$-topology for any $m \geq 0$.

In order to construct a limit, let us view all the spaces $\mathbb{C}^{N_{j}}$ as embedded as linear subspaces of one common Hilbert space $H$ with unit sphere $\mathbb{S}_{H}$. Choose a dense countable sequence of points $\left\{p_{t}\right\}_{t \geq 0}$ in $\tilde{S}$. Then, since the unitary group of $H$ acts transitively on (complex) orthonormal bases of $H$, there is a sequence of unitary transformations $F_{j}$ of $H$ such that (after taking a subsequence in $j$ if necessary) for any given $t \geq 0$, the sequence $F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}\left(p_{t}\right)$ converges to a point in $\mathbb{S}_{H}$ as $j \rightarrow \infty$. Since the maps $\psi_{j}$ are uniformly Lipschitz on compact subsets, by an Arzelà-Ascoli argument, $F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}$ converges in the $C^{0}$-topology on compact subsets to a limit locally Lipschitz map

$$
\psi_{\infty}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{H}
$$

Because of the uniform $C^{k}$-bound on compact subsets, the convergence can be upgraded to $C^{k}$-convergence on compact subsets for any $k \geq 0$. For instance, in order to check local $C^{1}$-convergence, note that the second derivative $D^{(2)}\left(F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}\right)$ is uniformly bounded on compact subsets, so a Taylor expansion at each $p_{t}$ ensures that the first derivative at $p_{t}, D^{(1)}\left(F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}\right)\left(p_{t}\right)$, must converge, which is enough to show local $C^{1_{-}}$ convergence. For later use, after picking a subsequence if necessary $j_{l}$, we can assume that $\lim _{l \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}_{\text {ren }}\left(S, \rho_{j_{l}}\right)$ exists and is the liminf of the original sequence.

We now bound the energy of the limit map $\psi_{\infty}$. By the lower semicontinuity of the energy under convergence of harmonic maps, Lemma 1.5 and Lemma 4.3:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\psi_{\infty}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right) & =\lim _{\delta \rightarrow 0} \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\psi_{\infty}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right) \\
& \leq \lim _{\delta \rightarrow 0} \liminf _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\psi_{j}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S} \cap \tilde{A}_{\delta}}\right) \\
& =\lim _{\delta \rightarrow 0} \liminf _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left[\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)+\sum_{p \in \operatorname{Punc}_{S}} \frac{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{p_{j}}(p)^{2}}{4 \pi} \log \frac{1}{\delta}\right] \\
& =\liminf _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence,

$$
\mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho^{\prime}\right) \leq \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\psi_{\infty}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right) \leq \liminf _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)
$$

Next, let us explain how the limit map $\psi_{\infty}$ determines a unitary representation $\rho^{\prime}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{End}(H)$. For the sake of simplicity, we write "converge" and " $\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}$ " instead of "subsequentially converge".

By reducing the Hilbert space $H$, we will assume without loss of generality that no closed linear (strict) subspace of $H$ contains $\psi_{\infty}(\tilde{S})$. In other words, there is a sequence of points $z_{1}, z_{2}, \ldots, z_{i}, \ldots \in \tilde{S}$, such that the vectors $\psi_{\infty}\left(z_{1}\right), \psi_{\infty}\left(z_{2}\right), \ldots \in \psi_{\infty}(\tilde{S})$ are linearly independent, and after applying the Gram-Schmidt procedure, we get a Hilbert orthonormal basis $e_{1}=\psi_{\infty}\left(z_{1}\right), e_{2}, \ldots, e_{i}, \ldots$ of $H$. Note that $F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}\left(z_{i}\right)$ converges to $\psi_{\infty}\left(z_{i}\right)$. Thus, for any finite set of complex numbers $a_{j}, \sum_{i} a_{i} F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}\left(z_{i}\right)$ converges to $\sum_{i} a_{i} \psi_{\infty}\left(z_{i}\right)$. Next, for any $g \in \pi_{1}(S)$, and any $z_{i}$, set

$$
\rho^{\prime}(g) \psi_{\infty}\left(z_{i}\right):=\psi_{\infty}\left(g \cdot z_{i}\right)=\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left(F_{j} \circ \rho_{j}(g) \circ F_{j}^{-1}\right) \circ F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}\left(z_{i}\right)
$$

Since $e_{i}$ is a finite linear combination of $\psi_{\infty}\left(z_{1}\right), \psi_{\infty}\left(z_{2}\right), \ldots, \psi_{\infty}\left(z_{i}\right)$, the above formula defines by linearity a linear transformation $\rho^{\prime}(g): H \rightarrow H$ which is easily checked to be unitary, since $\rho_{N}(g)$ is unitary. Moreover, by the formula above again, we clearly have $\rho^{\prime}\left(g g^{\prime}\right)=\rho^{\prime}(g) \rho^{\prime}\left(g^{\prime}\right)$ since the analogue property holds for $F_{j} \circ \rho_{j}(.) \circ F_{j}^{-1}$. This finishes the definition of the unitary representation $\rho^{\prime}$ and the map $\psi_{\infty}$, which by construction is $\pi_{1}(S)$-equivariant with respect to $\rho^{\prime}$, namely $\psi_{\infty}$ is an element of $\mathscr{H}_{S, \rho^{\prime}}$ :

$$
\rho^{\prime}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{End}(H), \quad \psi_{\infty}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{H}
$$

We claim that for all $f \in \ell^{1}\left(\pi_{1}(S), \mathbb{C}\right)$,

$$
\left\|\rho^{\prime}(f)\right\| \leq \limsup _{j}\left\|\rho_{j}(f)\right\|
$$

Indeed, by (30) and using the previous notations, for any finite linear combination $f=\sum_{k} \alpha_{k} g_{k} \in \mathbb{C}\left[\pi_{1}(S)\right]$, and any finite linear combination $\sum_{i} a_{i} \psi_{\infty}\left(z_{i}\right)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\rho^{\prime}(f)\left(\sum_{i} a_{i} \psi_{\infty}\left(z_{i}\right)\right)\right\| & =\left\|\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left(F_{j} \circ \rho_{j}(f) \circ F_{j}^{-1}\right)\left(\sum_{i} a_{i} F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}\left(z_{i}\right)\right)\right\| \\
& =\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\left(F_{j} \circ \rho_{j}(f) \circ F_{j}^{-1}\right)\left(\sum_{i} a_{i} F_{j} \circ \psi_{j}\left(z_{i}\right)\right)\right\| \\
& \leq\left(\limsup _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\rho_{j}(f)\right\|\right)\left\|\sum_{i} a_{i} \psi_{\infty}\left(z_{i}\right)\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

That is enough to show the claim (32). Since by assumption $\rho_{j}$ converges strongly, we get from (32) that for all $f \in \ell^{1}\left(\pi_{1}(S), \mathbb{C}\right)$ :

$$
\left\|\rho^{\prime}(f)\right\| \leq\left\|\lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}(f)\right\|
$$

Thus by Theorem 6.2, $\rho^{\prime} \prec \lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}$ and so by $C^{*}$-simplicity of $\pi_{1}(S)$ [Pow75] [dLH07],

$$
\rho^{\prime} \sim \lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}
$$

By (33), Lemma 1.12, Theorem 1.11 and Corollary 3.4 (1) applied to $\rho:=\rho^{\prime}$ and $\nu:=\lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}$, we find that

$$
\frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)=\mathrm{E}(S, \bigoplus^{\infty} \lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}) \leq \mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho^{\prime}\right)
$$

Combined with (29), this finishes the proof. For future use, we record the following consequence:

$$
\mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho^{\prime}\right)=\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\psi_{\infty}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)=\liminf _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)=\frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)
$$

Remark 4.5. M. Magee pointed out that, when $\mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)$ is finite, Proposition 4.4 alternatively follows from a generalization of the resolvent method of [HM23] applied to flat $\mathbb{C}^{N}$-bundles over hyperbolic surfaces [Zar22] [Hid23]. Our proof of Proposition 4.4 is different and has the advantage of producing a limit harmonic map, which will be crucial in the proof of the main part of Theorem 0.4 in the next subsection.

4.2. Convergence of the pullback metric. To finish the proof of the main theorem, it remains to identify the limit of the pullback metric. For each $N$, let $\psi_{j}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}$ be a harmonic representative of $\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)$. Let $g_{\text {Eucl }}$ be the standard Euclidean metric on $\mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}$ and let $g_{\text {hyp }}$ be the unique complete, conformal, hyperbolic metric on the Riemannian surface $S$. By equivariance of $\psi_{j}$, the pullback metric $\left(\psi_{j}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}$ descends to a metric on $S$ still denoted by $\left(\psi_{j}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}$.

Theorem 4.6. If $\rho_{j}$ strongly converges, then the harmonic representatives $\psi_{j}$ satisfy

$$
\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left(\psi_{j}\right)^{*} g_{\mathrm{Eucl}}=\frac{1}{8} g_{\mathrm{hyp}}
$$

in the $C^{\infty}$ topology on compact subsets of $S$.

Proof. Let $\rho^{\prime}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{End}(H), \psi_{\infty}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}_{H}$ be the limit unitary representation and limit map constructed in (31) in the proof of Proposition 4.4. The map $\psi_{\infty}$ is the limit of a subsequence of $\psi_{j}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}$, after composing with unitary transformations $F_{j}$. The convergence is smooth on any compact subset of $\tilde{S}$. By (33), we have $\rho^{\prime} \sim \lambda_{\pi_{1}(S)}$.

By (34), $\left.\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\psi_{\infty}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)=\mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho^{\prime}\right)=\frac{\pi}{4}(2 \mathbf{g}+\mathbf{n}-2)\right)$. By the equality case of Corollary 2.4 ,

$$
\left(\psi_{\infty}\right)^{*} g_{H}=\frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}
$$

where $g_{\text {hyp }}$ is the unique hyperbolic metric on $S$ compatible with its conformal structure.
By the way $\psi_{j}$ converges to $\psi_{\infty}$, for any fixed compact subset $G$ of $\tilde{S}$, we have for any $m \geq 0$ :

$$
\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty}\left\|\psi_{j}^{*} g_{\mathrm{Eucl}}-\frac{1}{8} g_{\mathrm{hyp}}\right\|_{C^{m}(G)}=0
$$

This implies the desired conclusion that $\psi_{j}^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}$, viewed as a Riemannian metric on $S$, converges to $\frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}$ on compact subsets of $S$ in the $C^{\infty}$ topology.

# 5. APPLICATIONS 

5.1. Limit of the $N$ th average renormalized energy. Let $S$ be a punctured Riemann surface and suppose that $\pi_{1}(S)$ is a free group $F_{k}$ of rank $k \geq 2$, namely $S$ has at least one puncture. Its Euler characteristic is

$$
\chi(S)=1-k
$$

Let $g_{\text {hyp }}$ be its hyperbolic metric. Unitary representations of $F_{k}$ into $U(N)$ are in one-to-one correspondence with $k$-tuple $\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{k}\right) \in U(N)^{k}$. For $N \geq 1$, set
$\mathbb{E}_{N}(S):=$ average of $\mathrm{E}_{\text {ren }}(S, \rho)$ over all unitary representations $\rho: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow U(N)$
where the average is taken with respect to the Haar measure on $U(N)^{k}$. This measure is preserved by the action of the outer automorphism group $\operatorname{Out}\left(F_{k}\right)$ (see [CMP19, Lemma 1.5]), which means that $\mathbb{E}_{N}(S)$ does not depend on the identification $\pi_{1}(S) \approx F_{k}$, and in fact induces a function on moduli space of Riemann surfaces. When $\pi_{1}(S)$ is not free (a case we will not consider here), the definition of $\mathbb{E}_{N}(S)$ can naturally be generalized by taking the average of $\mathrm{E}_{\text {ren }}(S, \rho)$ on the moduli space of unitary representations with respect to the Atiyah-Bott-Goldman symplectic volume form [AB83] [Gol84].

In the next statement, by "random sequence of unitary representations $\tau_{N}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow$ $U(N)$ ", we mean a sequence sampled on $\Pi_{N \geq 1} U(N)^{k}$ from the standard product Haar probability measure. Theorem 0.1 is a corollary of the following theorem:
Theorem 5.1. Let $S$ be a punctured Riemannian surface with $\pi_{1}(S)$ isomorphic to a free group of rank $k \geq 2$. Consider a random sequence of unitary representations $\tau_{N}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow U(N)$. For each $N \geq 1$, let $\psi_{N}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow\left(\mathbb{S}^{2 N-1}, g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)$ be a harmonic representative of $\left(S, \tau_{N}\right)$. Then

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \tau_{N}\right)=\frac{\pi}{4}(k-1) \text { almost surely }
$$

and $\left(\psi_{N}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}$ converges to $\frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}$ almost surely in the $C^{\infty}$-topology on compact sets of $S$. In particular,

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{E}_{N}(S)=\frac{\pi}{4}(k-1)
$$

Proof. If clearly suffices to prove the first part of the theorem because by Lemma 3.3, $\mathrm{E}_{\text {ren }}(S, \rho) \leq C_{S}$ for a constant depending only on $S$. By [CM14], a random sequence $\tau_{N}$ : $\pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow U(N)$ strongly converges almost surely (see Theorem 6.4 in the Appendix). The statement then follows from Theorem 0.4.

# 5.2. Special immersions of surfaces into $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. 

Theorem 5.2. Let $\epsilon>0$. For any closed hyperbolic surface $\left(\Sigma, g_{\text {hyp }}\right)$, there exists a finite degree covering $\left(\Sigma^{\prime}, g_{\text {hyp }}\right)$ and a harmonic immersion into a Euclidean unit sphere

$$
\psi:\left(\Sigma^{\prime}, g_{\text {hyp }}\right) \rightarrow\left(\mathbb{S}^{n_{\epsilon}}, g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)
$$

such that $\psi^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}$ is $\epsilon$-close to $\frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}$ in the $C^{2}$-topology.
Proof. Set $S$ be the Riemann surface corresponding to $\left(\Sigma, g_{\text {hyp }}\right)$. By [LMH25] (see Theorem 6.7 in the Appendix), there is a sequence of unitary representations

$$
\rho_{j}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow U\left(N_{j}\right)
$$

which strongly converges, and such that $\rho_{j}\left(\pi_{1}(S)\right)$ is a finite subgroup of $U\left(N_{j}\right)$. The kernel $\operatorname{ker}\left(\rho_{j}\right)$ is thus a finite index subgroup of $\pi_{1}(S)$. This implies that, if $\psi_{j}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow$

$\mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}$ is a harmonic representative of $\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)$, the map $\psi_{j}$ factors as follows: there is a finite covering $S^{\prime}$ of $S$ with fundamental group $\operatorname{ker}\left(\rho_{j}\right)$, and a map

$$
\psi_{j}^{\prime}: S^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}
$$

such that

$$
\psi_{j}=\psi_{j}^{\prime} \circ \Pi
$$

where $\Pi: \tilde{S} \rightarrow S^{\prime}$ is the natural projection. This $\psi_{j}^{\prime}$ is a harmonic map and by Theorem 0.4 , the pullback metric $\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}$ converges to $\frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}$ and in particular $\psi_{j}^{\prime}$ is an immersion for large $j$. The theorem is proved.

Remark 5.3 (Meaning of $\frac{1}{8}$ ). For $\epsilon>0$ small, the harmonic map $\psi$ in Theorem 5.2 is given by $n_{\epsilon}+1$ coordinates functions $(\psi)^{i}:\left(\Sigma^{\prime}, g_{\text {hyp }}\right) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ which are almost Laplace eigenfunctions with eigenvalue 2. Indeed, the image $\psi\left(\Sigma^{\prime}\right)$ is almost a minimal surface in $\mathbb{S}^{n_{\epsilon}}$, and coordinate functions on 2-dimensional minimal surfaces in Euclidean unit spheres are Laplace eigenfunctions with eigenvalue 2 by [Tak66]. But 2 is exactly the bottom of the Laplace operator on the rescaled hyperbolic plane $\left(\mathbb{H}^{2}, \frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}\right)$. Optimistically, it could be that Theorem 5.2 holds (resp. cannot hold) if the factor $\frac{1}{8}$ is replaced by any larger (resp. smaller) constant.
5.3. Almost hyperbolic minimal surfaces in spheres. Consider a Riemann surface $T$ and

$$
\varphi: T \rightarrow\left(M, g_{M}\right)
$$

a branched minimal immersion of $T$ into some Riemannian manifold $\left(M, g_{M}\right)$. Then the pullback metric $\varphi^{*} g_{M}$ is a nondegenerate Riemannian metric everywhere on $T$ except at a discrete set of points. It induces a well-defined metric on $T$, and its Gaussian curvature, denoted by $K_{\varphi^{*} g_{M}}$, is well-defined almost everywhere. The map $\varphi$ is said to be simple if there is no nontrivial branched covering map $f: T \rightarrow \bar{T}$ and there is no $\operatorname{map} \hat{\varphi}: \bar{T} \rightarrow M$ so that $\varphi=\hat{\varphi} \circ f$.

Theorem 5.4. For any $j \geq 1$, there are a closed Riemann surface $T_{j}$ and a simple, branched, minimal immersion

$$
\varphi_{j}: T_{j} \rightarrow\left(\mathbb{S}^{n_{j}}, g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)
$$

such that
(1) $\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\operatorname{Area}\left(T_{j}, \varphi_{j}^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)} \int_{T_{j}}\left|K_{\varphi_{j}^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}}+8\right|=0$,
(2) $\left(T_{j}, \varphi_{j}^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)$ Benjamini-Schramm converges to $\left(\mathbb{H}^{2}, \frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}\right)$ as $j \rightarrow \infty$.

Benjamini-Schramm convergence was originally a notion of convergence for random graphs. It has been recently extended to manifolds, see for instance Abért-Biringer

[AB22, Section 1]. In our statement, it means the following: there are regions $\Omega_{j} \subset T_{j}$ such that

$$
\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\operatorname{Area}\left(\Omega_{j}, \varphi_{j}^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)}{\operatorname{Area}\left(T_{j}, \varphi_{j}^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)}=1
$$

and for any $R>0$ and $x_{j} \in \Omega_{j}$, the metric $R$-ball in $\left(T_{j}, \varphi_{j}^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)$ centered at $x_{j}$ converges in the Gromov-Hausdorff topology to an $R$-ball in $\left(\frac{n \pi^{2}}{2 \pi}, \frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}\right)$.

Proof of Theorem 5.4. For (1): Take $S$ to be the round unit 2-sphere with three points removed. Let $\Sigma$ be the underlying topological surface, which is a thrice-punctured sphere. It is well-known that the Teichmüller space of $\Sigma$ is reduced to a single point $\mathscr{T}_{\Sigma}=\left\{\mu_{0}\right\}$, and that the mapping class group of $\Sigma$ (i.e. the set of isotopy classes of the group of orientation-preserving homeomorphisms of $\Sigma$ ) is isomorphic to symmetric group $\mathbf{S}_{3}$ (the permutation group of $\{1,2,3\}$ ) [FM11, remark after Proposition 10.5, and Proposition 2.3]. Let $g_{\text {hyp }}$ be the complete finite area hyperbolic metric on $\Sigma$, unique up to isometries. The elements of the mapping class group are represented by the "obvious" symmetries of $\left(\Sigma, g_{\text {hyp }}\right)$.

We have $\pi_{1}(S) \approx F_{2}$. By [BC19], namely Theorem 6.5 in the Appendix, and Lemma 6.6, there exists a sequence of unitary representations $\rho_{j}: \pi_{1}(S) \rightarrow U\left(N_{j}\right)$ which strongly converges, such that $\rho_{j}\left(\pi_{1}(S)\right)$ is finite, and such that $\rho_{j}$ satisfies $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho_{j}}(p)=0$ for each puncture $p$ of $S$ (see (3) for the definition of $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\rho_{j}}(p)$ ). In particular

$$
\mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)=\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ren}}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)<\infty
$$

by Corollary 3.3 (1) and Lemma 1.4.
By Theorem 1.7, there is a harmonic representative $\psi_{j}: \tilde{S} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}$ of $\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)$, so thanks to (37), $\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\psi_{j}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)=\mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)$. Because the Teichmüller space of $\Sigma$ is trivial, actually $\mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)=\operatorname{Area}\left(\Sigma, \rho_{j}\right)$ (see Definition 1.9). By Theorem 1.10, $\psi_{j}$ is both harmonic and weakly conformal, namely it is a branched minimal immersion. Hence,

$$
\operatorname{Area}\left(\mathbf{D}_{S},\left(\left.\psi_{j}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)=\mathrm{E}\left(\left.\psi_{j}\right|_{\mathbf{D}_{S}}\right)=\mathrm{E}\left(S, \rho_{j}\right)=\operatorname{Area}\left(\Sigma, \rho_{j}\right)
$$

Since $\rho_{j}\left(\pi_{1}(S)\right)$ is finite, $\operatorname{ker}\left(\rho_{j}\right)$ has finite index in $\pi_{1}(S)$. Thus, we can consider the connected finite covering $S_{j}$ of $S$, with fundamental group $\operatorname{ker}\left(\rho_{j}\right)$. The map $\psi_{j}$ factors through a branched minimal immersion $\psi_{j}^{\prime}: S_{j} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}$ with finite total energy. Let $\bar{S}_{j}$ be the closed Riemann surface obtained from $S_{j}$ by closing the punctures. By the removable singularity theorem of Sacks-Uhlenbeck [SU81] [CM11, Theorem 4.26], $\psi_{j}^{\prime}$ extends across the punctures to a branched minimal immersion still denoted by

$$
\psi_{j}^{\prime}: \bar{S}_{j} \rightarrow \mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}
$$

As a consequence,

$$
\psi_{j}(\tilde{S})=\psi_{j}^{\prime}\left(\bar{S}_{j}\right)
$$

is a closed, branched, minimal surface in $\mathbb{S}^{2 N_{j}-1}$.

By Theorem 0.4, the pullback metrics $\left(\psi_{j}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}$, which descends to a metric on $S$ by equivariance of $\psi_{j}$, converges smoothly to $\frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}$ on any compact subsets of $S$. Hence, the Gaussian curvature of $\left(\psi_{j}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}$ converges smoothly to -8 away from the punctures. It remains to control the Gaussian curvature around the punctures, which is achieved with general properties of minimal surfaces. Let $\alpha_{j}$ be the degree of the covering $S_{j} \rightarrow S$. Let $\delta \in(0,1]$ be a small constant. Let $A_{\delta} \subset S, \tilde{A}_{\delta} \subset \tilde{S}$ be defined as in (14), and let $\tilde{A}_{j}$ be the image of $\tilde{A}_{\delta}$ in $S_{j}$ by the projection $\tilde{S} \rightarrow S_{j}$. Write

$$
\tilde{Z}_{j}:=\bar{S}_{j} \backslash \tilde{A}_{j}
$$

Both $\tilde{A}_{j}$ and $\tilde{Z}_{j}$ implicitly depend on $\delta$. By (38), and Theorem 0.4,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\operatorname{Area}\left(\bar{S}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)}{\alpha_{j}}=\frac{\pi}{4} \\
& \lim _{\delta \rightarrow 0} \liminf _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\operatorname{Area}\left(\tilde{A}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)}{\operatorname{Area}\left(\bar{S}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)}=1 \\
& \lim _{\delta \rightarrow 0} \limsup _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\operatorname{Area}\left(\tilde{Z}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)}{\operatorname{Area}\left(\bar{S}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)}=0 \\
& \lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\operatorname{Area}\left(\bar{S}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)} \int_{\tilde{A}_{j}}\left|K_{\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}}+8\right|=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $\partial A_{\delta}$ is a union of embedded curves around punctures with geodesic curvature constant equal to 8 with respect to the rescaled hyperbolic metric $\frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}$ on $S$. $$
\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\alpha_{j}} \operatorname{Length}\left(\partial \tilde{Z}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)=\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\alpha_{j}} \operatorname{Length}\left(\partial \tilde{A}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\text {Eucl }}\right)=\operatorname{Length}\left(\partial A_{\delta}, \frac{1}{8} g_{\text {hyp }}\right)

$$

where the inequality comes from the branched points and the disk topology (an easy way to see this inequality is to observe that each branched point can be locally smoothed in a neighborhood to a smooth immersion such that the integral of the Gaussian curvature

$$

So combining (39) and (42, we find

$$
\limsup _{\delta \rightarrow 0} \limsup _{j \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{\operatorname{Area}\left(\bar{S}_{j},\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\mathrm{Eucl}}\right)} \int_{\bar{Z}_{j}}\left|K_{\left(\psi_{j}^{\prime}\right)^{*} g_{\mathrm{Eucl}}}\right|=0

\begin{aligned}
